articles.author: Gaming News
articles.description:
TL;DR: MachineGames—the studio behind Indiana Jones and The Great Circle (VGOTY 2024) and Wolfenstein II—has quietly axed an unannounced game, according to a LinkedIn post spotted by a Twitter user. No clues on what the project was—fans hoping for Wolfenstein 3 (given the cliffhanger in New Colossus) will have to keep dreaming.
Meanwhile, MachineGames is busy cooking up DLC for Indiana Jones and, with Microsoft’s ZeniMax takeover backing them, there’s plenty of $$$ and talent for future sequels (Jones 2 or Wolf 3?). Until the studio spills more beans, the mystery title remains buried.
articles.title: Indiana Jones and Wolfenstein developer MachineGames has cancelled an unannounced project

articles.author: Gaming News
articles.description: TL;DR: Elden Ring: Nightreign blasted past 250K concurrent Steam players just 30 minutes after launch—hitting over 306K within an hour—and even outpaced the combined peaks of Dark Souls II, III and Remastered. Its multiplayer co-op focus clearly gave it a serious boost, putting it at more than a quarter of OG Elden Ring’s all-time high of 953K.
articles.title: Elden Ring Nightreign player count surges to more than 300,000 players in a Hour of release.

          As you probably know, the state of the gaming industry has been very problematic in recent months and years. There are numerous issues there, but the most
        
      
          
        techcrawlr.com
articles.title: "Morale Has Been At An All-time Low," Respawn's Designer Says On Social Media

articles.author: Gaming News
articles.description:
TL;DR: In their latest SEC 10-K filings, EA and Take-Two are flagging a new kind of risk: reputational and legal fallout from weaving AI (especially generative AI) into game development and business processes. They warn that if they mishandle “social and ethical issues” around AI, it could erode player trust and damage their brands—so they’ve tacked it onto their usual laundry list of industry risks (think pandemics, internet outages, franchise dependence, etc.).
Most big studios (yes, even Nintendo) are dabbling in AI at the concept stage, and regulators make public companies call out anything that might hurt the bottom line. Execs like Take-Two’s Strauss Zelnick see AI as a booster for efficiency—not a job killer or creative substitute—while acknowledging these digital tools bring both promise and potential headaches.
articles.title: EA admits that embracing AI could lead to fans losing confidence in the company and its brands.

articles.author: AR/VR News
articles.description:
TL;DR: A team from Samsung Electronics and POSTECH has created a super-thin (500 µm) single-layer waveguide display for AR eyewear by using achromatic metagratings—arrays of nanoscale gratings that diffract red, green and blue light at the same angle. Unlike bulky, multi-layer waveguides (or earlier metasurface attempts), this design slashes weight and size while boosting brightness, color uniformity and user comfort.
They used a custom stochastic topology-optimization algorithm to fine-tune the nanostructures, achieving high-quality, full-color images without chromatic distortion. The result is a more compact, ergonomic AR headset platform that could soon bring crisp digital overlays to everyday glasses.
articles.title: Samsung Research: Single-layer waveguide display uses achromatic metagratings for more compact augmented reality eyewear

articles.author: AR/VR News
articles.description:
Viture’s next XR flex

Hot on the heels of its Pro XR glasses, Viture just dropped a teaser for a whole new lineup of smart specs. They’ll be the first AR glasses rocking Sony’s latest Micro-OLED panels for crisper, brighter visuals and a wider field of view, plus full 6DoF tracking for real-deal spatial movement.
More ways to rock AR

Instead of one design, Viture’s cooking up multiple frame styles—think Ray-Ban Meta vibes—and even a built-in camera for snapping pics or overlaying info. In short, they’re aiming to push “spatial computing” from buzzword to reality (and look good doing it).
articles.title: Exclusive: Viture is teasing next-gen XR glasses — here's what we know about them

articles.author: AR/VR News
articles.description:
Apple Glasses will offer one big advantage that AirPods can’t match - 9to5Mac
        
      
        
          Apple Glasses are reportedly coming next year, and despite lots of feature overlap, they’ll have one advantage AirPods can’t match.
        
      
          
        9to5mac.com
articles.title: Is it more weird to wear earbuds in social situations than wearing Smartglasses ?

articles.author: AR/VR News
articles.description:
TL;DR: After nearly nine years and over 6,000 articles, Tomislav Bezmalinović is bidding farewell to MIXED. What began as a passion-driven VR blog in 2016 thrived through the Quest 2 boom and Metaverse hype—only to be crushed by a 90% traffic drop from a Google core update. Falling ad revenue, shrinking Plus subscriptions and a youth-driven shift toward TikTok and YouTube turned a vicious cycle into an inevitable end for the site in its current form.
Despite MIXED’s closure, Tomislav remains optimistic about VR’s future. He sees an industry still in its infancy—fragile, dominated by one marketplace, but ripe for innovation as “VR natives” grow up. He’s off to write about XR at Heise Online, grateful to readers and eager to follow the next chapter of virtual reality.
articles.title: MIXED is shutting down, one of the two best XR news websites

articles.author: AR/VR News
articles.description:
TL;DR: Google CEO Sundar Pichai sat down with Nilay Patel right after I/O 2025 to dive into what he calls a “new phase of the AI platform shift.” The highlight? AI Mode in Search, which dynamically spins up custom results pages—complete with charts and mini-apps—and will gradually fold into regular Google Search. Pichai says these new AI products mark “research becoming reality,” and he’s confident they’ll finally deliver returns on Google’s years of AI investment.
They also tackled the hot-button issues: publishers (backed by the News Media Alliance) screaming “theft” over AI summaries, future AR eyewear from Project Moohan, the big OpenAI–Jony Ive hardware deal, and looming antitrust battles—most notably the DOJ’s push to spin off Chrome. Through it all, Pichai insists Google’s committed to sending more traffic to the open web and won’t tweak search results for political pressures.
articles.title: Google CEO: Next year millions of people will try AI smartglasses - We'll have products in the hands of developers this year

articles.author: Science News
articles.description:
Doctors Deliver Verdict on TikTok's 'Mouth Taping' Trend : ScienceAlert
        
      
        
          If you struggle with 'mouth breathing' while you sleep, from the occasional snore or full-blown obstructive sleep apnea, you – or your sleep-deprived partner – may be looking for ways to fix it.
        
      
          
        sciencealert.com
articles.title: Review of 10 Papers on Viral 'Mouth Taping' Trend Finds an Absence of Evidence to Support the Health Claims

articles.author: AI News
articles.description:
TL;DR: Mark Zuckerberg and Palmer Luckey have officially buried the hatchet and teamed up—Meta + Anduril style—to build “Eagle Eye,” an AI-powered extended-reality system for the US military. The project will mash up Meta’s hardware know-how with Anduril’s Lattice AI platform to create smart headsets and wearables that overlay augmented-reality visuals, letting troops spot distant threats in real time.
This alliance isn’t just about cooler goggles—it’s a clear sign that Big Tech is doubling down on defense. By pooling resources and expertise, the two companies are positioning themselves at the forefront of next-gen military gear, blurring the lines between consumer VR/AR and battlefield-ready tech.
articles.title: Mark Zuckerberg and Palmer Luckey end their beef and partner to build extended reality tech for the US military

articles.description: Imagine: China deploys hundreds of thousands of autonomous drones in the air, on the sea, and under the water—all armed with explosive warheads or small missiles. These machines descend in a swarm toward military installations on Taiwan and nearby US bases, and over the course of a few hours, a single robotic blitzkrieg overwhelms the US…

articles.author: The Editors
articles.description: Separating AI reality from hyped-up fiction isn’t always easy. That’s why we’ve created the AI Hype Index—a simple, at-a-glance summary of everything you need to know about the state of the industry. Large language models confidently present their responses as accurate and reliable, even when they’re neither of those things. That’s why we’ve recently seen…
articles.title: The AI Hype Index: College students are hooked on ChatGPT
